intro: Suaeda argentinensis, commonly known as Argentine saltbush, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves that help it retain water in arid environments. The plant typically grows in saline soils and is adapted to coastal and inland desert regions. Its small, greenish flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it produces small, round fruits that contain seeds. Suaeda argentinensis plays a role in stabilizing soils and is sometimes used in ecological restoration projects.
